channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israel-Hamas War: Gaza’s Main Hospital Struggles to Keep Patients Alive
item.description: As fighting raged around Al-Shifa Hospital, a loss of power caused the deaths of patients, including an infant. Four other hospitals were forced to evacuate on orders from the Israeli military.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Khader Al Zanoun/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: One Man’s Mission to Give Soviet World War II Soldiers Decent Burials
item.description: Konstantin Dobrovolsky searches for the remains of soldiers left to rot on the battlefield almost 80 years ago. Then he had to bury his own son, who fought in a war he despises.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Burying the remains of Soviet soldiers at the mass funeral in Smolensk. Volunteers were able to identify only four of the dead.

item.title: Youth Struggle to Find Jobs in South Africa, Where 6 in 10 Are Unemployed
item.description: Portia Stafford has a high school diploma in hospitality and three certificates from job training programs. She is among a generation of ambitious Africans who spend their days chasing an elusive opening.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Gulshan Khan
item.media:credit: Gulshan Khan for The New York Times

item.title: Hamas Assailants on Oct. 7 Ambushed Israeli Bomb Shelters
item.description: Hamas’s assault on southern Israel began with a barrage of rockets, sending scores of people into roadside refuges. Then gunmen came to hunt them.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner and Amit Elkayam
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times

item.title: Philippine Ship Is an Unlikely Outpost That Is Angering China
item.description: After multiple maritime clashes, the Philippines invited journalists on a mission to resupply the Sierra Madre. A reporter for The Times was given rare access.
item.dc:creator: Camille Elemia
item.media:credit: Camille Elemia for The New York Times

item.title: Pro-Palestinian March Held in London as Police Scuffle With Far Right
item.description: The gathering drew an estimated 300,000 people, the police said, making it one of the largest protests in Britain in recent years. Before it began, far-right demonstrators scuffled with officers.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia, Stephen Castle and Esther Bintliff
item.media:description: Protesters at a pro-Palestinian march on Sunday in London.

item.title: Texas Bishop Loudly Critical of Pope Francis Is Removed
item.description: It was a rare move that was a measure both of Bishop Joseph Strickland’s outspoken criticism of the supreme pontiff of his faith and of Francis’ frustration with ultraconservatives in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Kirby Lee/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
item.media:description: Bishop Joseph Strickland of Tyler, Texas, leading a protest in June against the Los Angeles Dodgers for honoring a pro-L.G.B.T.Q. group.

item.title: Chapter 4: The Wedding
item.description: It was the moment two families had long waited for. But Arti feared it could be the end of her dreams for a career.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall, Amanda Taub, Shalini Venugopal Bhagat and Andrea Bruce
item.media:description: Arti Kumari and Rohit Kumar during their wedding in her village, Belarhi.

item.title: Russia Launches Missile at Kyiv for First Time in Weeks, Ukraine Says
item.description: The attack was part of an overnight barrage that suggested Moscow was testing air defenses before another potential winter campaign against Ukraine’s energy infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Missile traces over Kyiv, Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: Australia Offers Climate Refuge to Tuvalu Citizens, but Not All
item.description: Low-lying Tuvalu has reached a deal with its large Pacific neighbor to address the challenge of rising oceans, but it is not planning to pack up and go.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A view of part of Tuvalu from 2019. Rising sea levels have been causing the land to disappear.

item.title: Taylor Swift Brings Her Eras Tour to Argentina, Shaking El Monumental
item.description: The singer-songwriter began her Eras Tour outside North America, and some Swifties in Argentina camped out for more than five months.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Sarah Pabst for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taylor Swift performing in Buenos Aires on Thursday night.

item.title: Who Is Stefanos Kasselakis, the Syriza Leader Upending Greek Politics?
item.description: The rapid ascent of Stefanos Kasselakis, a former Goldman Sachs trader and Greece’s first openly gay party leader, has gripped the nation. But his leadership is dividing the country’s main opposition party.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Stefanos Kasselakis has made waves since becoming leader of the Greek opposition party Syriza.

item.title: Deadly Johannesburg Fire Exposed Years of Neglect
item.description: Officials blame immigrants and liberal housing laws, but a Times investigation found the entrenched problems that turned downtown Johannesburg into a blighted tinderbox.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel, Selam Gebrekidan and John Eligon

item.title: Iran and Saudi Arabia Call for Gaza Cease-Fire at Summit
item.description: The leaders of both Islamic countries appeared to put aside their own historical animosities to present a united stand against Israel’s Gaza war.
item.dc:creator: Ahmed Al Omran and Yara Bayoumy
item.media:description: Secretary General of the Organization of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) Hissein Brahim Taha, Saudi Arabia’s Foreign Minister Prince Faisal bin Farhan Al Saud and Secretary-General of the Arab League Ahmed Aboul Gheit attend a press conference during the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) summit to discuss Gaza crisis, in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia on Saturday.

item.title: Iran’s president visits Saudi Arabia for the first time since the two mended ties.
item.dc:creator: Matt Surman and Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: A handout picture from the Saudi Press Agency showing President Ebrahim Raisi of Iran, left, upon his arrival in Saudi Arabia on Saturday.

item.title: Our Merch, Ourselves
item.description: What do the bands and brands whose merchandise we buy say about who we are and what we value?
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: For Both Trudeau and Biden, Polls Suggest an Uphill Political Path
item.description: The economy, and particularly inflation, has soured voters on both leaders, polls indicate, though well in advance of upcoming votes.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: President Biden and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau have seen their poll ratings slump.

item.title: They Left Gaza to Work in Israel. Now They’re Stranded.
item.description: Thousands of workers from Gaza have been trapped in the West Bank since the Hamas attacks on October 7. Their Israeli work permits have been canceled, and they’re deeply worried about their families back home.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cassel, Ayman Abu Ramouz and Caroline Kim

item.title: Life in Gaza City: Privation, Rationing and Desperate Fear
item.description: Mohammad Matar, a civil engineer, and his family have remained in the city even as Israeli ground forces continue their relentless assault.
item.dc:creator: Yousur Al-Hlou
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:description: Smoke and flares rise over Gaza City during an Israeli strike in the Gaza Strip, as seen from southern Israel on Friday.

item.title: Macron Mourns Civilian Deaths, Urges an Israeli Cease-Fire
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France, speaking at a humanitarian aid conference in Paris about the Israel-Hamas war.

item.title: Street Battles Rage in Gaza City Ruins, as Residents Flee on Foot
item.description: The Biden administration, which has pressed Israel to do more to safeguard civilian lives, said Israel had agreed to steps to help people flee the northern Gaza Strip and receive aid.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Rosenberg and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: Israeli troops next to a destroyed building in the Gaza Strip on Wednesday.

item.title: Gaza City Hospitals Are Caught in Deadly Crossfire
item.description: Battling Hamas fighters, Israeli forces are “closing in” on hospitals where thousands of people are stranded, while the chief U.S. diplomat says “far too many Palestinians have been killed.”
item.dc:creator: Thomas Fuller, Aaron Boxerman, Malachy Browne and Neil Collier
item.media:credit: Khader Al Zanoun/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Patients and displaced people line a corridor in Al Shifa hospital on Friday.

item.title: After a Scare, Croatian Authorities Declare Coca-Cola Products Safe
item.description: After worries that a man had been sickened by his soft drink, the authorities said that it was an isolated incident and not a cause for wider concern.
item.dc:creator: Sopan Deb and Melina Delkic
item.media:description: An employee removing Coca-Cola products from shelves at a supermarket in Zagreb on Wednesday.

item.title: In New York City, Antisemitic Hate Crimes Soared Last Month
item.description: Several high-profile incidents are being investigated as hate crimes in New York, where anti-Jewish incidents more than tripled in October compared with last year.
item.dc:creator: John Leland
item.media:credit: Dolly Faibyshev for The New York Times
item.media:description: The intersection in New York’s Upper East Side neighborhood where apartment rooftops were vandalized with antisemitic graffiti.

item.title: Megan Rapinoe, Emma Hayes and a Women’s Soccer Crossroads
item.description: Rapinoe, who helped define U.S. soccer for a decade, is retiring after this week’s N.W.S.L. final. Hayes, the Chelsea coach, will try to put her stamp on it next.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: Megan Rapinoe will play her final club game on Saturday, for OL Reign in the N.W.S.L. final.

item.title: Blinken Says ‘Far Too Many Palestinians Have Been Killed’ in Gaza
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken’s comments were the latest indication that the Biden administration is increasingly concerned about the civilian death toll in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken talking to reporters in New Delhi on Friday after a diplomatic tour through Middle Eastern and Asian nations.

item.title: UK Prisons Are Nearly Full
item.description: In England and Wales, prisons are almost full, part of a troubling trend that experts say creates unsafe conditions for both those in detention and the staff who manage them.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Many prisons in Britain are already overcrowded, including Wandsworth Prison in London, from which a prisoner facing terrorism charges briefly escaped in September. It was holding more than 600 prisoners over its normal capacity.

item.title: Prince Harry Can Proceed With a Lawsuit Against Daily Mail Publisher
item.description: A judge rejected an attempt by the publisher to have Harry’s case thrown out, paving the way for the trial to move ahead.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Prince Harry has three ongoing lawsuits against British tabloid publishers.

item.title: Thousands Wait at Ukraine Border After Polish Truckers Blockade It
item.description: As drivers protested what they say is unfair competition from their Ukrainian counterparts, the waiting time at one checkpoint was estimated to be seven days.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Vehicles blocked access to the Polish-Ukrainian border crossing in Dorohusk, Poland, in protests this week.

item.title: Biden and Xi to Seek to Stabilize Relations in California Meeting
item.description: Taiwan, election interference and the war in the Middle East will be on the agenda, officials say. But the leaders will also look for ways to strengthen ties.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers and Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: President Biden and President Xi Jinping of China last year in Indonesia. They plan to meet again while attending the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit in San Francisco next week.

item.title: Rebels Gain Ground from Military Junta in Myanmar
item.description: An offensive by an alliance of armed ethnic groups based in the north has seized key towns, galvanized groups elsewhere and spotlighted the military’s weakness.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Members the Ta’ang National Liberation Army in Shan State earlier this year. The group is one of three armed ethnic groups that have joined forces in recent weeks, making significant gains against Myanmar’s military, which seized power in a coup in early 2021.

item.title: U.S. Seeks to Resume Military Dialogue with Beijing
item.description: The Joint Chiefs chairman said in a letter to his Chinese counterpart that restoring communications was crucial to avoiding misunderstandings.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.media:description: Gen. Charles Q. Brown Jr., the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said that re-establishing military dialogue between two of the world’s most powerful militaries was a goal of the Biden administration.

item.title: How Tropical Parakeets Took Over Brussels
item.description: After a small group of parakeets were released from a zoo in Brussels in the 1970s, their numbers soared. A population increase has also occurred across the continent.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Max Pinckers for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rose-ringed parakeet roosting in a tree in the Flagey neighborhood of Brussels.

item.title: Colombia Wants to Recover the San José’s Shipwreck’s Treasure
item.description: The San José galleon was destroyed in 1708, sinking with goods now worth billions. Colombia’s government is planning a recovery, but not everyone wants to see the shipwreck brought to the surface.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin and Genevieve Glatsky

item.title: Germany Restricts Pro-Palestinian Protests Amid Israel-Hamas War
item.description: The country’s authorities have banned many protests in the name of fighting antisemitism. Critics say such restrictions are discriminatory.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A protest in Berlin in solidarity with Palestinians. Some European governments, citing security fears, have imposed limitations on these demonstrations, raising concerns about civil liberty violations.

item.title: Gonorrhea Is Becoming Drug Resistant. Scientists Just Found a Solution.
item.description: A new antibiotic, zoliflodacin, is as effective as the current standard of care. Its creation may hasten the arrival of other needed antibiotics.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
item.media:description: Neisseria gonorrhoeae bacteria, which cause gonorrhea.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: A push from the U.S. for Israel to curtail its bombardment of Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers work in an artillery unit near the border with Gaza.

item.title: Hungary Fires Museum Director in Crackdown on L.G.B.T.Q. Depictions
item.description: A government campaign against what it calls “homosexual propaganda” is unsettling booksellers and has resulted in the firing of the director of one of the country’s leading museums.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Akos Stiller for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Hungarian National Museum has had long lines to see the World Press Photo exhibition after the government ordered that only adults should be allowed to enter.

item.title: Korean President’s Battle Against ‘Fake News’ Alarms Critics
item.description: He calls fake news an enemy that threatens democracy. Critics of President Yoon Suk Yeol say he is silencing journalists in the name of fighting disinformation.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea answering reporters’ questions as he arrived for work last year. He has since ended the practice and adopted a more guarded stance toward the news media.

item.title: Crocodile Bites Man. Man Bites Back.
item.description: A surprising tale of Northern Territory chutzpah.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A saltwater crocodile caught in the Northern Territory, at Sydney Wildlife World in Sydney, Australia.

item.title: Israel Accuses Freelance Photographers of Advance Knowledge of Oct. 7 Attack
item.description: The New York Times said there was “no evidence” to support such claims about its freelancer.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: A photograph taken by Yousef Masoud for The Associated Press on Oct. 7 shows a breach in the security fence between Gaza and Israel and a disabled Israeli tank. The image was taken more than 90 minutes after the attack began.

item.title: Omegle Shuts Down as Founder Acknowledges Crime on Video Chat Site
item.description: Omegle’s popularity surged during the pandemic. But critics said that it let online sexual predators go unchecked.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina

item.title: Vatican Says Transgender People Can Be Baptized and Become Godparents
item.description: A document approved by Pope Francis lays out nuanced guidance in keeping with his vision of a more inclusive church, but it does not amount to a policy change in the church, the Vatican says.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz, Elisabetta Povoledo and Ruth Graham
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: In his 10-year papacy, Pope Francis has sought to make the Roman Catholic Church more welcoming to L.G.B.T.Q. people, though he opposes same-sex marriage.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Israel Expands Pauses in Combat
item.description: Plus, Hollywood is coming back to life.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fleeing toward the southern Gaza on Wednesday.

item.title: Germany Remembers Kristallnacht at a Fraught Moment
item.description: As reports of antisemitism surge in Germany and elsewhere, commemorations of the Nazi pogrom have taken on special resonance this year.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze and Graham Bowley
item.media:description: The slogan “Never again is now” was projected onto the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin, marking the 85th anniversary of Kristallnacht.

item.title: Israeli Forces Have Limited Time in Gaza, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: Israel’s response to the Hamas attacks has fueled sympathy around the world for the Palestinian cause even as Israel continues to bury its dead.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Adam Goldman
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israel launched a ground invasion in Gaza after the Oct. 7 attack by Hamas and Palestinian Islamic Jihad fighters in southern Israel.

item.title: International Olympic Committee Says It Was Target of Elaborate ‘Fake News’
item.description: Olympic officials said the effort included fabricated quotes about the Israel-Gaza war and a four-part, Netflix-style documentary.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:description: The Olympic rings in Paris, the site of next year’s Summer Games.

item.title: What Does ‘From the River to the Sea’ Mean?
item.description: The pro-Palestinian rallying cry has become a fixture of protests in the United States and was a focus of the congressional censure of Representative Rashida Tlaib. It has a fraught history.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian and Liam Stack
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Rashida Tlaib, Democrat of Michigan, was censured by House lawmakers after she used the pro-Palestinian slogan “from the river to the sea.”

item.title: Grass and Shrub Fires Destroy More Homes Than Forest Fires Across U.S.
item.description: Grassland and shrubland fires burn more land and destroy more homes across the United States than forest fires, a new study found.
item.dc:creator: Nadja Popovich
item.media:description: Firefighters battled a grass fire in March 2022 in Boulder, Colo.

item.title: U.K. Home Secretary’s Article in Times of London Stirs Political Storm
item.description: The future of Suella Braverman hung in the balance after she wrote an incendiary opinion article. Downing Street said the piece was unauthorized.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Suella Braverman, Britain’s home secretary, outside 10 Downing Street in London last month.

item.title: Iceland’s Blue Lagoon Closes After Thousands of Earthquakes
item.description: The tourist attraction, a geothermal spa that is popular with Americans, said it would “carefully monitor the seismic developments” as a precautionary measure.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Blue Lagoon has proactively chosen to temporarily suspend operations for one week, despite the authorities not raising the current level of uncertainty during this period of seismic activity,” the Blue Lagoon said in a statement.

item.title: Sánchez’s Deal With Catalonia Separatists Creates Turmoil in Spain
item.description: Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez’s agreement with Catalan separatists will likely keep him in power, but it has provoked an upheaval.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: People protesting in Madrid near Spain’s Socialist party headquarters this week over negotiations to grant amnesty to people involved with Catalonia’s failed 2017 independence bid.

item.title: In Mexico, Surveillance Orders That Read Like a Political Power List
item.description: The Mexico City attorney general’s office ordered the phone records of politicians and officials, court filings show. Many of the people targeted say they were singled out for political reasons.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib, Natalie Kitroeff and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Under the tenure of President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico, the country’s military has repeatedly spied on journalists, human rights advocates and even senior members of his own administration.

item.title: The Artistry of Nashenas Speaks to the Afghanistan He Had to Leave Behind
item.description: For his fellow exiles, Sadiq Fitrat Nashenas, an 88-year-old star from a golden era, evokes the Afghanistan they left behind, and one that could have been.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Jim Huylebroek
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nashenas at an assistant’s home in Huizen, The Netherlands, last month.

item.title: Luis Díaz’s Kidnapped Father Is Freed in Colombia
item.description: Luis Manuel Díaz was abducted 12 days ago by a guerrilla group called the National Liberation Army.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Esteban Vanegas/United Nations Mission in Colombia
item.media:description: Luis Manuel Díaz after being freed from National Liberation Army guerrillas on Thursday.

item.title: Greenland’s Glaciers Are Melting Faster
item.description: Some glaciers on the island are melting at double the rate of just a few decades ago.
item.dc:creator: Delger Erdenesanaa

item.title: A Bundle of 18th-Century Love Letters Is Unsealed at Last
item.description: More than 100 letters, addressed to French sailors, were never delivered. They remained unopened for nearly 250 years, until a historian found them in Britain’s archives.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Letters to sailors on France’s Galatée warship, which was captured by the British in 1758.

item.title: Archaeologists Look for Traces of Missing in Ashes of Hamas Oct. 7 Attack
item.description: A team of about 15 have recovered the remains of at least 60 people so far, most of them from an Israeli village that suffered devastating losses.
item.dc:creator: Natan Odenheimer
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners gathered at the funeral of Lili and Ram Itamari, who were killed in Kfar Aza by Hamas gunmen on Oct. 7.

item.title: Palestinian Authority Open to Gaza Role if U.S. Backs 2-State Solution
item.description: The organization, which oversees the West Bank, says it will consider helping run Gaza after the war — if Washington pushes for the creation of a Palestinian state alongside the Israeli one.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Displaced people from Gaza City relocating to the south of Gaza Strip on Wednesday.

item.title: Titanic Dinner Menu Is Up for Auction in England This Weekend
item.description: The menu, dated April 11, 1912, is part of a larger sale of maritime items taking place this weekend in England.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: A first-class dinner menu from April 11, 1912, the day the Titanic left Queenstown, Ireland, for New York.

item.title: Heirloom Opens First U.S. Direct Air Capture Plant
item.description: The technique is expensive but it could help fight climate change. Backers hope fast growth can bring down costs.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:description: A carbon capture plant in Tracy, Calif.
